'''Universal Disk Format''' ('''UDF'''), also known by the specifications '''ISO/IEC 13346''' and '''[[Ecma International|ECMA]]-167''', is a vendor-neutral and medium-agnostic [[file system]] for [[computer data storage]]. In practice, it has been most widely used for [[DVD]]s and newer [[optical disc]] formats, supplanting [[ISO 9660]] and is used for (re)writable [[Optical disc|optical media]]. UDF is developed and maintained by the [[Optical Storage Technology Association]] (OSTA).
+
'''Universal Disk Format''' ('''UDF'''), also known by the specifications '''ISO/IEC 13346''' and '''[[Ecma International|ECMA]]-167''', is an [[open format|open]] vendor-neutral and medium-agnostic [[file system]] for [[computer data storage]]. In practice, it has been most widely used for [[DVD]]s and newer [[optical disc]] formats, supplanting [[ISO 9660]] and is used for (re)writable [[Optical disc|optical media]]. UDF is developed and maintained by the [[Optical Storage Technology Association]] (OSTA).
Normally, [[optical disc authoring software|authoring software]] will master a UDF file system in a batch process and write it to optical media in a single pass. But when [[packet writing]] to rewriteable media, such as [[CD-RW]], UDF allows files to be created, deleted and changed on-disc just as a general-purpose [[filesystem]] would on removable media like [[floppy disk]]s and [[flash drive]]s. This is also possible on write-once media, such as [[CD-R]], but in that case the space occupied by the deleted files cannot be reclaimed (and instead becomes inaccessible).
Normally, [[optical disc authoring software|authoring software]] will master a UDF file system in a batch process and write it to optical media in a single pass. But when [[packet writing]] to rewriteable media, such as [[CD-RW]], UDF allows files to be created, deleted and changed on-disc just as a general-purpose [[filesystem]] would on removable media like [[floppy disk]]s and [[flash drive]]s. This is also possible on write-once media, such as [[CD-R]], but in that case the space occupied by the deleted files cannot be reclaimed (and instead becomes inaccessible).
